newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West Coast light crude eases in thin trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West Coast light crude eases in thin trade.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crude prices were seen easing on Tuesday in quiet talk as traders returned from the three-day holiday weekend, traders said.
"Everybody is taking a breather and waiting" for release of the weekly American Petroleum Institute inventory estimates, one West Coast trader said.

"It's pretty quiet," said a trader with BP America, which on Friday sold a 400,000 barrel cargo of benchmark Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude at a discount of $1.75 a barrel under July West Texas/Intermediate (WTI).
Last week's deal between BP America, a unit of British Petroleum Plc, and Texaco Trading and Marketing increased the ANS discount by 25 cents a barrel, traders said.
Meanwhile, ARCO Pipeline Co said it would accept all nominations on its Line 63 crude line between Los Angeles refineries and fields in Bakersfield, Calif.

In the cash market, technical selling on the NYMEX and perceptions of a lack of refiner demand for prompt July barrels pushed prices lower, with WTI ending the day at $20.70 a barrel bid, $20.80 asked.
